div.p:
Module 3, Engaging Your
Organization For Maximum Impact.
This module will discuss best practices

for organizing an interdisciplinary
sustainability team,

and determining your
facility's initial baseline

and subsequent benchmarks
for energy and water use,

greenhouse gas emissions,
and sustainability measures.

In this module, we will
cover important aspects
related to team engagement

and the measurement of
operational performance.
This stage of the process

includes the formation
of a sustainability team,
the measurement of baseline performance,

and the establishment of
performance benchmarks.

In the following slides, we
will discuss the importance

of identifying and
engaging key team members

to play important roles
using software tools
for energy performance benchmarking

such as ENERGY STAR Portfolio
Manager or RETScreen,

establishing clear baselines
for tracking progress,
and developing an effective action plan

based on well-informed
goals and strategies.

Energy and facility managers
are directly involved

in a range of energy and
resource efficiency improvements

from new construction to
retrofits to equipment upgrades
and installation of controls.

Successful projects require
the coordination of individuals
with diverse roles and responsibilities.
Buy-in and support are critical
at individual and group levels.

Incorporating sustainability
into current projects

usually requires you to
expand your project team

to include various
resource-specific disciplines.
A sustainability or green team

that includes an
interdisciplinary perspective

can provide comprehensive
and effective solutions.

A green team is usually led
by a sustainability champion
who is committed and enthusiastic

about making a change towards
a more sustainable facility.

Sustainability champions
should surround themselves

with a core team comprised
of key stakeholders

such as energy managers,
property managers,

procurement officers, or
sustainability coordinators.

Additional team members
should also participate
in the green team discussions
to provide an outside perspective
on the initiatives at hand.
Additional team members

include human resources
representatives, financial officers,
O&M contractors, and others.
Sustainability operations
are unique to the facility's content
so gather your team accordingly.
Work with management to help identify
and recruit employees with a role to play

such as those involved in
procurement, recycling,

and other waste management
related job tasks.
The size of your team

may depend on the size
of your organization
but should have enough members
to explore holistic solutions.
In all cases, a sustainability team

will be responsible for
selecting, coordinating,
and implementing a project.

It will also track progress
including benchmarking,
monitoring, and evaluating performance.
Finally, the team effort
should include recording best practices,

delivering training,
communicating results,

celebrating achievement,
and providing recognition.

Human behavior is a
frequently overlooked element

in achieving aggressive
building performance goals.

Changing behavior requires
understanding occupant
and user habits and motivations.

Be sure to include individuals
on your sustainability team

that can help pinpoint and
address occupant behavior issues

and promote change using
targeted outreach and education.
The most common performance inefficiencies
caused by human behavior

include new or unfamiliar
building technologies;

lack of understanding,
education, and training;

inaccessible information or
ineffective feedback mechanisms;

and cultural norms and
institutional protocols
that do not foster sustainability.

Deploying an action
plan to address barriers
has three main parts.

First, creating an effective
communications plan
includes the project's objectives,
how they will be implemented,
and expectations for occupants.

Messages should be
delivered and reinforced

by senior management and
sustainability team members

in person, in presentations,
and on the site's intranet.

Second, education and training
should provide the foundation

for continuous improvement
through workshops
or other training.
Third, effective feedback tools
should include focus groups and surveys.
The key for successful messaging
is to show that the project is aligned

with the organization's mission
and sustainability vision

and promotes the occupant's
stewardship responsibility.

The action plan should integrate
the following principles;
awareness of the need for change,

desire to participate
and support the project,
knowledge of what is required,

ability to implement new
skills and associated behavior,
reinforcement to keep change in place.
Your facility's long-term success

will hinge on an ability to
collectively create and adopt
a sustainability ethic.

Studies show that fostering
a culture of sustainability
requires supportive resources and policies

that empower change,
well-trained program staff,
and engaged senior management.
A successful sustainability policy
will set the stage for long-term success,

clearly define what sustainability
means for employees,

and demonstrate how it
helps the department
meet its critical mission.
Prior to any launch, prepare a briefing
to gain support of senior management.
This step is critical to the success
of a sustainability action plan
as the support from senior management
can make or break any given initiative.
Once the team has been assembled,

the first step is to
organize a kickoff meeting

to develop a plan and
schedule future meetings.

At the kickoff meeting,
introduce team members and roles
and set expectations.
The next step is to determine a baseline
of building performance
and establish a performance benchmark
for which to aim for.

From there, team members
can identify problems

and opportunities for
improvement and as a group,

justify efforts to move
forward and make a change.
The first project that a team takes on
should be one that is simple
and provides quick results and payback.

This will help build momentum
and gain further support
from senior management.

Your team's first task should
be to establish a baseline

and benchmark of energy
consumption, water use,
and greenhouse gas emissions.

A baseline establishes a
facility's energy or water use
for a set period as a point of reference
for future comparison.
A baseline provides the starting point

for setting goals and
evaluating future efforts
and overall performance.

12 months of data
provides a solid baseline
for most facilities.
Benchmarking is a process to account for

and compare a metered
building's current performance
against its own baseline

or against other similar
types of buildings.
Benchmarking can chart progress

on several important datasets,
which can help inform goals;

set targets and timelines;
document resource use;
verify uses and costs of energy, water,
and greenhouse gas emissions;
pinpoint energy and water leaks;
and identify billing errors.
ENERGY STAR Portfolio Manager

is an online management and
tracking tool most widely used

for measuring energy and
water use in buildings.

It includes features to manage
energy and water consumption,
rate building energy performance,

estimate your carbon footprint,
set investment priorities,
verify and track progress of projects,
gain recognition, access related tools,

and track other
third-party certifications.

While all buildings can
use Portfolio Manager
to track and assess energy and water use,

there are currently only
seven building types eligible
for an energy score in Canada.

These building types are K-12
schools, commercial offices,

hospitals, supermarkets, and
food stores, medical offices,

senior care communities, and
residential care facilities,
and ice/curling rinks.

If your building type is not
currently eligible for a score
keep in mind that Natural Resources Canada

will be developing new
scores on a progressive basis
and your building type could be next.
Taking the right steps

to ensure that benchmarking
data is consistent and accurate

may take some time, but
will lay a solid foundation
for sustainability initiatives.
Be sure to develop a benchmarking plan

to outline a strategic
approach to the process.
Document a clear picture

of how the data is currently
being measured and used.
Consider bringing an outside consultant

or third-party provider, like
an energy service company,
to guide the process.
Consistently train all staff involved

in the collection of
data and input process.

Use available tools and resources
to make compliance easier.
Another powerful tool

for the management of energy
performance is RETScreen.
Developed by the government of Canada,

RETScreen Expert is a
software for energy efficiency

and renewable energy
project feasibility analysis

as well as ongoing energy
performance analysis.
This tool has many functions

and can be used to perform
portfolio-wide analysis,
collect information on a facility,
perform benchmarking analysis,
track energy and greenhouse gas emissions,
and for general performance analysis.

This tool is used widely
throughout government and industry.

Some of the key users
include 3M, CRH Canada,
Oxford Properties, Canadian Tire,

The Coalition of Ontario
Universities, National Defence,
Public Services & Procurement Canada,
and Natural Resources Canada.

In Module 3, we
discussed best practices
to engage your organization
in developing specific measurable goals.
This process involves engaging all those

who play important roles
in achieving these goals
using available tools

such as ENERGY STAR Portfolio
Manager or RETScreen,

and establishing a baseline
and benchmarking your progress.

From there your team can
develop a specific action plan

based on well-informed
goals and strategies.

In module four, we discussed
steps related to developing,

evaluating, selecting, and
implementing sustainable measures

and explore common options
for sustainable upgrades.
